  physical_appearance: This is a set of brass vase container containing several spades and tongs. The base is a circular and curved
 with four small holes. The body of the vase is engraved with floral designs. The spades and tongs sit inside the vase through the opening at the top.

  subject_terms_1: ceremonial objects Peranakan religious ceremonies flower (motif) altar components

  subject_terms_2: Motifs Rites and ceremonies Peranakan (Asian people) Altars Vases Ceremonial objects

  subject_terms_3: Religious life and practices

  sgcool_label_text: This brass vase contains several spades and tongs. The vase is engraved with flowers and the faces of phoenixes on its side. The spades are used to scoop ashes and incense into censers and burners and the tongs are used to remove old incense buds.\r\n\r\nThis item is donated by the family of prominent Peranakan
 Ong Sam Leong (b. 1857
 Singapore – d. 7 February 1918
 Singapore). It comes from his ancestral home of Bukit Rose
 formerly at 259 Bukit Timah Road. Ong was a well-known successful businessman who made is money in the mining of phosphate on Christmas island
 which was historically a territory of colonial Singapore. \r\n

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a set of brass vase container containing several spades and tongs. The base is a circular and curved, with four small holes. The body of the vase is engraved with floral designs. The spades and tongs sit inside the vase through the opening at the top.

metadata.sgcool_label_text:
This brass vase contains several spades and tongs. The vase is engraved with flowers and the faces of phoenixes on its side. The spades are used to scoop ashes and incense into censers and burners and the tongs are used to remove old incense buds.

This item is donated by the family of prominent Peranakan, Ong Sam Leong (b. 1857, Singapore – d. 7 February 1918, Singapore). It comes from his ancestral home of Bukit Rose, formerly at 259 Bukit Timah Road. Ong was a well-known successful businessman who made is money in the mining of phosphate on Christmas island, which was historically a territory of colonial Singapore.
